title: Zhejiang Province sends team of 5 Ophthalmologists to Mali for short term medical aid mission
description: Between January 11 and January 19, 2020, a team of 5 Chinese doctors from the Eye Center of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University School of Medicine traveled to Mali where they carried out free cataract surgeries for 41 patients, most of whom were impoverished. The doctors were stationed at Mali Hospital, in Bamako. In addition to providing direct care, the team also held demonstrations and lectures for the resident ophthalmologists at Mali hospital. The team was sent by the Health Commission of Zhejiang Province and funded by the Chinese government..    On January 16th, the Chinese Ambassador Zhu Liying visited the team at the hospital and donated a box of medications to the hospital in honor of his visit (see project #94889).
staff_comments: 1. In Chinese, the medical mission was referred to as the '送光明' 援外医疗任务
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Zhejiang Province sends team of 5 Ophthalmologists to Mali for short term medical aid mission

# Description
Between January 11 and January 19, 2020, a team of 5 Chinese doctors from the Eye Center of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University School of Medicine traveled to Mali where they carried out free cataract surgeries for 41 patients, most of whom were impoverished. The doctors were stationed at Mali Hospital, in Bamako. In addition to providing direct care, the team also held demonstrations and lectures for the resident ophthalmologists at Mali hospital. The team was sent by the Health Commission of Zhejiang Province and funded by the Chinese government..    On January 16th, the Chinese Ambassador Zhu Liying visited the team at the hospital and donated a box of medications to the hospital in honor of his visit (see project #94889).
justification: Project is focused on providing medical aid and training, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Short-term medical aid mission, cataract surgeries, medical training, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Ambassador to Mali donates small box of medicines to Mali Hospital (linked to #93589)
description: On January 16, the Chinese Ambassador to Mali, Zhu Liying, visited the ophthalmology team from China temporarily stationed at Mali Hospital in Bamako (see project #93589 for more information on the medical team). The ambassador was accompanied on his visit by Mali's minister of health, Michel Sidibe.  In honor of his visit, the Ambassador donated a small box of medicines to the hospital. The exact number and type of medications is unknown.
combined_text:

evidence: Small box of medicines donated to Mali Hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government dispatches 26th medical team to Mali Hospital
description: In 2020, the Chinese government dispatched the 26th medical team to Mali Hospital. The medical team's purpose was to help manage the COVID-19 crisis in Mali. The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs reports that on July 18, 2020, Chinese Ambassador to Mali Zhu Liying visited the team and congratulated their efforts so far.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 26th medical team to Mali Hospital

# Description
In 2020, the Chinese government dispatched the 26th medical team to Mali Hospital. The medical team's purpose was to help manage the COVID-19 crisis in Mali. The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs reports that on July 18, 2020, Chinese Ambassador to Mali Zhu Liying visited the team and congratulated their efforts so far.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team dispatch to Mali Hospital, COVID-19 crisis management focus

title: China Eximbank provides a $57.564 million USD loan to Star Bulk Carriers Corp. to refinance existing debt and a China Merchants Bank Limited lease agreement
description: On December 1, 2020, the Export-Import Bank of China entered into a $57.564 million USD loan facility agreement with Marshall Islands-incorporated shipping company Star Bulk Carriers Corp The facility was used by Star Bulk to refinance an aggregate outstanding loan of $41.982 million USD. The original loan was a $310 million USD facility with China Merchants Bank Leasing (CMBL) for the vessels Star Gina 2GR, Star Charis, Star Wave, and Star Suzanna. The facility had a final maturity date of January 2029 (a maturity period of eight years). The facility was secured by (i.e. collateralized against) the first priority mortgages on the four vessels.  The facility was drawn down in four tranches; a $13.209 million USD tranche to refinance Star Wave that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments of $330,000 USD and a balloon payment of $2.642 million USD; a $26.175 million USD tranche to refinance Star Gina 2GR that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments of $654,000 USD and a balloon payment of $5.235 million USD; a $9.09 million USD tranche to refinance Star Charis that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments; and a $9.09 million USD tranche to refinance Star Suzanna that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides a $57.564 million USD loan to Star Bulk Carriers Corp. to refinance existing debt and a China Merchants Bank Limited lease agreement

# Description
On December 1, 2020, the Export-Import Bank of China entered into a $57.564 million USD loan facility agreement with Marshall Islands-incorporated shipping company Star Bulk Carriers Corp The facility was used by Star Bulk to refinance an aggregate outstanding loan of $41.982 million USD. The original loan was a $310 million USD facility with China Merchants Bank Leasing (CMBL) for the vessels Star Gina 2GR, Star Charis, Star Wave, and Star Suzanna. The facility had a final maturity date of January 2029 (a maturity period of eight years). The facility was secured by (i.e. collateralized against) the first priority mortgages on the four vessels.  The facility was drawn down in four tranches; a $13.209 million USD tranche to refinance Star Wave that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments of $330,000 USD and a balloon payment of $2.642 million USD; a $26.175 million USD tranche to refinance Star Gina 2GR that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments of $654,000 USD and a balloon payment of $5.235 million USD; a $9.09 million USD tranche to refinance Star Charis that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments; and a $9.09 million USD tranche to refinance Star Suzanna that was repayable in 32 equal quarterly installments.
justification: Project involves financial refinancing of existing debt for shipping vessels, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan facility agreement for refinancing existing debt, secured by shipping vessels, no mention of environmental or energy transition aspects

title: CMB Leasing enters into sale and leaseback agreement valued at $38.5 million with Capital Product Partners L.P. for the acquisition of the M/V Athos (Linked to Project ID#92125)
description: On January 20, 2020, CMB Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. (CMB Leasing) and Capital Product Partners L.P., a Marshall Islands-incorporated shipping conglomerate, entered into a sale and leaseback agreement valued at USD 38.5 million for the acquisition of Capital Product Partners' M/V Athos. The lease agreement has a duration of five years, with an interest rate of LIBOR plus 2.55%. The agreement includes a purchase option to acquire the vessel upon expiration of the lease for USD 22.5 million and requires a payment of USD 7.5 million to CMB Leasing if the option is not exercised. There are also additional purchase options beginning with the first anniversary of the agreement.  The full amount of USD 38.5 million was drawn on January 23, 2020.  An identical agreement was signed for the M/V Athos' sister ship, M/V Aristomenis on January 20, 2020 (captured in project #92125).
staff_comments: 1. Sale and leaseback (or sale-leaseback) agreements are generally considered to be off-balance-sheet hybrid debt products.2. AidData has calculated LIBOR as being 1.839%, based on the 6-month LIBOR in January 2020 (https://www.global-rates.com/en/interest-rates/libor/american-dollar/2020.aspx). Hence, the interest rate has been calculated as (1.839% + 2.55% = 4.389%).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
CMB Leasing enters into sale and leaseback agreement valued at $38.5 million with Capital Product Partners L.P. for the acquisition of the M/V Athos (Linked to Project ID#92125)

# Description
On January 20, 2020, CMB Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. (CMB Leasing) and Capital Product Partners L.P., a Marshall Islands-incorporated shipping conglomerate, entered into a sale and leaseback agreement valued at USD 38.5 million for the acquisition of Capital Product Partners' M/V Athos. The lease agreement has a duration of five years, with an interest rate of LIBOR plus 2.55%. The agreement includes a purchase option to acquire the vessel upon expiration of the lease for USD 22.5 million and requires a payment of USD 7.5 million to CMB Leasing if the option is not exercised. There are also additional purchase options beginning with the first anniversary of the agreement.  The full amount of USD 38.5 million was drawn on January 23, 2020.  An identical agreement was signed for the M/V Athos' sister ship, M/V Aristomenis on January 20, 2020 (captured in project #92125).
justification: Project involves financial leasing agreement for a shipping vessel, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Sale and leaseback agreement for M/V Athos vessel, financial transaction focus

title: China donates 50 sewing machines to Mauritania to promote mask productions to fight against Covid-19 May 20, 2020
description: On May 20, 2020, the Chinese government donated 50 sewing machines to Mauritania. At the handover ceremony, Chinese Ambassador to Mauritania Zhang Jianguo stated that these machines must be used to promote mask production to help fight against Covid-19. The value of the machines is unknown.
combined_text:

# Description
On May 20, 2020, the Chinese government donated 50 sewing machines to Mauritania. At the handover ceremony, Chinese Ambassador to Mauritania Zhang Jianguo stated that these machines must be used to promote mask production to help fight against Covid-19. The value of the machines is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on health-related social development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of sewing machines for mask production to combat COVID-19, health sector focus

title: China donates ventilators to Mauritania for the fight against Covid-19 on August 22, 2020
description: On August 22, 2020, the Chinese government donated ventilators to Mauritania. The donation arrived at Nouakchott International Airport. The number of ventilators donated and their value is unknown.

title: China donates COVID-19 relief medical equipment to Mauritania on November 26, 2020
description: On November 26, 2020, the Chinese government donated COVID-19 relief medical equipment to Mauritania. This donation included ventilators, oxygen generators and other equipment. The exact value of the donation is unknown.  The handover certificate was signed in the handover ceremony by the representatives of the Chinese Embassy, the Mauritanian Capital Hospital, Friendship Hospital, and Kiffa Hospital.
combined_text:

HEALTH

The exact value of the donation is unknown.
